Famous Amos

I'm sure everyone has heard this by now, but if not here's a brief synopsis...In Florida, a 24 year old female teacher, Debra Lafave, is being accused of having sex on numerous occasions with a 14 year old male student. They had sex at least 5 times, including on a field trip to Sea World, at her house, and in her car. The sex was consentual. She is being charged with lewd and lascivious behavior. She is facing 2 counts, which could total 30 years in prison.
 
 Mary Letourneau, when she was 34, had sex with a 12 year old male student 300-400 times. She became pregnant with his child and was charged with statutory rape, but released on bail. She was not allowed to associate with the underage kid anymore. She did it anyway. She then served a 3 month sentence in jail and was freed. She was again caught having sex with the person she was not allowed to have contact with (he was still underage). She became pregnant by the kid again. She was sentenced to 7 years in prison.
 
 The problem I have is the double standard here. A month or so ago, a weatherman in Florida, Bill Kamal, was arrested for setting up a meeting for sex over the Internet with what he thought was a 14-year-old boy. The boy was actually an undercover federal agent. He was immediately dismissed from his job and is being denied bond. He is being charged with enticing a child, a penalty that can carry up to 30 years in prison. And he didn't even have sex with anyone.
 
 How come when females have sex with underage kids society doesn't put it in the same category as when a man does? When a man does, he is chastized for the rest of his life. When a female does, she's cool. Mr. Kamal didn't even have sex with anyone and will likely serve at least 4 years in prison. Letourneau repeatedly had sex with a kid and served 3 months. Ms. Lafave will likely receive probation or a very minimal sentence. Why are the punishments not equal?

I think the two cases are not apples to apples. If I was a judge on either of these cases, I would base my decision for punishment of the perps in this mode of thinking. . ..
 
 The 24 year old female school teacher was not in total control of the underage male . The young male was consenting, and I am sure could have stopped the affair at his will. The crime was indecent for sure, but the young male was not "forced" to bend to the 24 yr old females will. I would think that if the young male was being hurt by the older female, he would have done something about it. ...
 
 The on line grown male predator is a different ballgame all together. Even if it was not proven that he ever contacted a underage person in real life, he was working on it. Lets say the underage victim, was finally contacted by the on line predator in person, the child DID get trapped in the situation the predator wanted the kid in, instantly the child HAS NO control over the situation, and is HELPLESS to do anything about it. So, the molested child is basically ruined mentally, and possibly physically, from ever having a normal relationship with anyone when they grow up.. The lifelong effect from the molestation will forever haunt the young victims mind . He/she will spend their life in therapy ,fortunes on mood drugs, go though relationships and jobs like a barrel of peanuts. Basically the young persons life 's potential to be the best they could ever be, was taken away from them by a more powerful and controlling predator....
 
 So, in looking at the way the crime affects the "victim" as stated above, which would you now impose the higher sentence on ???

 For me, it is not even about a 24 y/o having sex with a 14 y/o. I think too much emphasis is placed on "legal" age in this country. Who does and does not have sex with who should be based on maturity, not age. I have known some 14 y/o people that are much more mature than many 18 or 19 y/o people. But the law is all we have to set a standard, a general guidline if you will. The problem I have with a case like this is that the teacher is in a position of authority over the student, and this creates a dangerous environment for the child. I do understand that the general perception is that a 14 y/o boy is more likely to want to have sex with a 24 y/o female teacher than a 14 y/o girl would want to have sex with a 24 y/o male teacher. I was once a 14 y/o boy, I understand how the hormones work. But perception does not make an act more or less legal, nor more or less moral. -JMHO

I'm not speaking for site administration, but to me it makes no difference where one comes from. International posts are, to me, welcome in that they often offer differing viewpoints from our (US) somewhat closed and prejudicial minds. 
 
 
 Thanks Georged, but I have not found Americans to have closed or prejudiced minds. I found most to be very generous, like yourself, towards foreigners.
 
 I know this is OT, but I was fortunate enough to spend my last Christamas school holidays in the USA, and I have to say that I got to really like American people. I visited an elderly lady in California who knows my family, and I travelled around a lot of the States by myself, (I told her that I was being met by another adult friend of the family, or she would not have let me go.)
 
 Anyway, most Americans were really great to me, even though I was a foreigner in your land. And even though I had trouble with your language, and Americans had even more trouble with my accent. :) 
 
 In my home country, the UK, and here in Australia, where I am an exchange student for a year, I hear lots of negative comments about 'the Yanks', but a lot of the people who say these things have never been to the USA.
 
 I reckon it's pretty stupid to typecast 300 million people as being one thing or another.
 
 But you do speak strange English, and no one understood me when I asked for 'chips', 'Devonshire Teas', directions to 'the coach station', or where the 'lift' was. LOL! :)

Thanks Georged, but I have not found Americans to have closed or prejudiced minds. I found most to be very generous, like yourself, towards foreigners.

 I think that we all have a tendency to paint people with too broad a brush. I think that most people are kind and generous regardless of country of origin.
 

 I know this is OT, but I was fortunate enough to spend my last Christamas school holidays in the USA, and I have to say that I got to really like American people. I visited an elderly lady in California who knows my family, and I travelled around a lot of the States by myself, (I told her that I was being met by another adult friend of the family, or she would not have let me go.)
 

 Well, you picked a nice place to visit, even if I wouldn't want to live there. California has lots to offer someone who spends most of his time in the fog-covered UK. That big, yellow thing in the sky is called the sun, by the way. ;)
 

 Anyway, most Americans were really great to me, even though I was a foreigner in your land. And even though I had trouble with your language, and Americans had even more trouble with my accent. :) 

 Americans typically are very hospitable to Brits. We have a long history of being strong allies, with the exception of a rocky start. And Brits, I've found, don't take themselves too seriously, as do Americans, so we're able to enjoy the common bond of humor.
 

 In my home country, the UK, and here in Australia, where I am an exchange student for a year, I hear lots of negative comments about 'the Yanks', but a lot of the people who say these things have never been to the USA.
 
 I reckon it's pretty stupid to typecast 300 million people as being one thing or another.

 The same is true here, but we don't hear too much bad press about Australia or the UK, so we generally have favorable impressions about both countries.
 

 But you do speak strange English, and no one understood me when I asked for 'chips', 'Devonshire Teas', directions to 'the coach station', or where the 'lift' was. LOL! :)
